;;T;;世界上没有多少城市;地方政府推出了家庭音乐节。很少有像 ;芝加哥;。在一个阳光明媚的周日下午，各个种族、各个年龄段的人们涌入市中心的千禧公园，许多人手里拿着毯子、冷藏箱和折叠露营椅。然而，一位与会者显然不受欢迎。日落时分，头条新闻法利“Jackmaster”Funk，一位著名的芝加哥 ;DJ; 受邀成为一位特邀嘉宾。当市长布兰登·约翰逊慢跑上台时，响起了震耳欲聋的嘘声。 45 秒之内，他再次离开，他看似简短的信息——芝加哥是“世界上最伟大的城市”，不足以平息异议的喧嚣。

;

;对政客发出嘘声是风城悠久的传统（精明的人知道最好的出现时间是早点，在人群开始喝酒之前）。然而，去年在芝加哥教师工会的支持下意外赢得选举胜利的约翰逊已经异常不受欢迎。根据 4 月下旬（即他当选一年后）进行的一项民意调查，只有 9% 的芝加哥居民认为他的工作“高于平均水平”；大多数人说他的工作低于平均水平。即使在非白人选民（他的基础）中，低于平均水平的支持率与高于平均水平的支持率也是四比一。

;;N;;OT THE; kings and queens present, nor the political leaders, nor even the Hollywood movie stars were at the centre of the ceremonies on June 6th commemorating the ;80th anniversary; of D-Day in ;Normandy;. It was the veterans. Some 200 made the journey to the beaches where most of them had landed ;in 1944;, launching the campaign that liberated France and, ultimately, defeated Hitler's Germany. “I did it for you!” read the slogan on the onstage screen that introduced the ceremony on Omaha Beach.

;

;Most of the veterans arrived in wheelchairs, their decorations—and a few tears—glistening in the spring sunshine. They were American, British and Canadian, and many spoke with disarming humility of the day when they plunged into the water under a hail of Nazi fire. “We did what we had to do,” said more than one. “We are all eternally in their debt,” declared Britain's King Charles, who attended a separate event at the British Normandy Memorial overlooking Gold Beach, where he spoke partly in French. For his part, Emmanuel Macron, the French president, said simply: “Nobody in France, in Normandy, can forget their sacrifice.”
